I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  At the request of the Government of Sri Lanka, the 2007 Country Programming Mission 
of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) made a provision for an advisory technical assistance 
(TA) to support institutional development assistance to the country’s water supply and sanitation 
sector.1 ADB’s TA Fact-Finding Mission visited Sri Lanka during 22–30 November 2007 and 
reached a preliminary understanding with the Government on the TA’s goals, purpose, scope, 
implementation, financing arrangements, and terms of reference. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.2 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Millions of people in Sri Lanka do not have access to adequate water supply and 
sanitation.  The  goals  of  the  National  Water  Supply  and  Drainage  Board  (NWSDB)  are  to  
(i) provide piped supply coverage for 40% of the population by 2011, (ii) ensure access to a safe 
water supply for 85% of the population by 2015; and (iii) provide piped sewerage coverage for 
3% of the population by 2011.3 The Government’s sector strategy and associated investment 
program focus on (i) providing support to rural and more deprived areas; (ii) investing through all 
three  tiers  of  government  mandated  to  provide  water  and  sanitation—central  government, 
provincial councils, and local authorities; (iii) establishing adequate regulatory and institutional 
frameworks;  (iv)  improving  performance  and  reducing  nonrevenue  water;  (v)  pursuing 
community-driven  schemes  in  rural  areas,  with  special  attention  to  women’s  participation;  
(vi) applying integrated urban water supply and management principles; and (vii) ensuring 
environmental integrity. In addition, the Government’s strategy clearly identifies the importance 
of sustainability and the need to secure adequate (yet socially acceptable) tariffs for water 
supply and sewerage schemes. Institutional strengthening is vital to achieving these targets. 
 
3.  Institutional  Arrangements  for  the  Water  Sector.  The  central  Government  is 
responsible  for  sector  policy,  regulation,  and  development  (Ministry  of  Water  Supply  and 
Drainage, MWSD, and Ministry of Urban Development and Sacred Areas). Provincial councils 
and local authorities are responsible for ensuring equitable resource allocation, and quality and 
standards of service under the national policy on rural water supply and sanitation. Prior to 1975, 
local authorities were primarily responsible for the provision of piped water and public wells. In 
1974,  through  an  act  of  Parliament,  NWSDB  was  established  to  be  the  primary  agency 
responsible for water supply and sanitation in the country. Subsequently several major urban 
water supply schemes operated by local authorities were transferred to improve coverage and 
service delivery. To date and in accordance with the country’s laws, NWSDB,4 urban and 
municipal councils, and pradeshiya sabhas retain their mandate to provide water and sanitation. 
Generally, NWSDB is responsible for planning, designing, constructing, and managing larger 
urban schemes; and supporting the development of rural schemes in areas declared under the 
NWSDB Act. All other rural areas come within the purview of local government or community-
based organizations.5 Capacity varies within the sector.6 While NWSDB’s capacity is generally

adequate, it needs support to implement its vision for gradual decentralization of operations, 
capital planning, and administrative and financial functions to the regions. In addition, support 
for autonomous regulation will help NWSDB achieve its goals of improving operating efficiency, 
customer satisfaction, and commercial viability.  
 
4.  Accountable  Regulation. 7  In  late  2002,  Parliament  created  the  Public  Utilities 
Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL), a multisector regulator for water, electricity, and ports. 
Although commissioners were appointed soon after, its functions could not be fully effected, 
partly due to delays in formulating and approving a water industry act.8 Subsequent efforts 
include the development of essential documentation and methodologies to monitor and improve 
financial performance, and customer and technical services.9 The Government is also finalizing 
the necessary legal revisions to bring NWSDB’s operations in line with the PUCSL Act and 
enable technical and economic regulation. Whilst the framework for operation is defined in the 
form of regulating guidelines; implementing systems, reporting mechanisms, protocols, and 
reviews are needed. Just as important, NWSDB is developing internal monitoring systems.  
 
5.  NWSDB’s Institutional Development: Corporate and Business Planning. NWSDB 
has developed 5-year corporate plans since 1996. The latest plan10 clearly identifies commercial 
viability,  and  greater  accountability  and  transparency  as  key  goals  to  be  pursued  by  the 
organization over the 5 year period. The plan sets forth specific objectives and countrywide 
targets to be achieved by NWSDB; however, shortcomings observed include (i) the need to link 
this to a business plan (and supporting financial projections) that translates action plans into 
financial terms, and key result areas into tangible financial targets or performance indicators that 
can  be  monitored;  and  (ii)  the  need  to  derive  national  goals  and  targets  from  regional 
information  and  develop  associated  monitoring  mechanisms.  The  corporate  plan  identifies 
corporate investment and asset management as key focus areas; these need to be linked to a 
realistic financial program. Moreover, NWSDB’s tariff methodology is based on two components 
that need to be carefully defined: (i) recurrent operating expenditure, as well as (ii) business and 
asset management plans that define the cost of capital over a 5-year period. The development 
of a business plan is essential to operationalize this methodology and NWSDB is taking the lead 
in its preparation.  
 
6.  NWSDB  Institutional  Development:  Decentralization  of  Responsibilities  and 
Functions. NWSDB has grown extensively since its creation in 1974, but its current size11 and 
excessively centralized management approach has led to several inefficiencies. In addition to its 
head  office,  NWSDB  is  currently  divided  into six  regional  support  centers  (RSCs)  and  23 
                                                 
7  Regulators are generally responsible for establishing, monitoring, and enforcing (i) discharge licenses and fees; 
(ii) service quality standards, as received by customers; and (iii) affordable and efficient tariffs. An effective 
regulatory framework will facilitate affordable delivery of adequate and safe water to consumers, especially the 
poor. Pricing rules try to balance the incentives to use water efficiently and social concerns such as quality of water 
supply, universal service goals, and subsidy schemes for the poor. 
8  The Supreme Court declared the most recent Water Sector Reform bill (2002) unconstitutional on the basis that the 
provision of piped water is a devolved responsibility in which the central Government has no power to legislate and 
the Government did not obtain the concurrence of the provinces. In terms of the constitution, all national policy 
formulation rests with the central Government.

3
regional  offices  throughout  Sri  Lanka.  Services  provided  (population  covered,  number  of 
connections,  quality  and  quantity  of  water  available),  infrastructure  and  water  production, 
staffing, operation and maintenance expenditure, and recovery vary significantly among the 
RSCs.12 In parallel, customer satisfaction, water resource availability, financial management, 
human resource management, and accountability vary across the country.13 Because the RSCs 
and  regional  offices  are  closer  to  the  beneficiary  population,  they  have  an  information 
advantage  in  identifying  citizens’  preferences  as  well  as  the  flexibility  to  respond  to  local 
conditions. As they act on this information to improve the quality and reliability of a variety of 
services, consumers will be willing to pay more for services, which in turn can secure the 
improvement and maintenance of the existing network, particularly in the most deprived areas.  
 
7.  NWSDB’s vision, as formulated in its latest corporate plan, proposes (i) decentralizing 
financial  and  administrative  authority;  to  be  followed,  on  a  performance  basis,  by 
decentralization of additional responsibilities; and (ii) transforming the RSCs into small business 
units with greater autonomy and accountability.14 The plan recognizes the need to strengthen 
capacities of the RSCs and regional offices to provide more efficient and responsive service 
delivery.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The TA will support Government and NWSDB efforts to improve water sector utilities’ 
management, especially financial management, and regional operations within the context of 
recent  sector  reforms  and  policies,  including  operationalization  of  credible  regulation. 
Consequently,  the  impact  of  the  TA  is  defined  as  improved  operating  efficiency  and 
management performance in the water sector. Its outcomes are (i) NWSDB service delivery 
functions  decentralized  and  (ii)  NWSDB  internal  monitoring  and  regulatory  systems 
operationalized.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will be divided into two components, each supporting one of the expected TA 
outcomes. The TA is to deliver four specific outputs: (i) regional benchmarking and regional 
business development plans, (ii) a capacity development program for decentralized service 
delivery, (iii) a 5-year asset management plan for NWSDB, and (iv) a program to facilitate 
internal monitoring and regulation in NWSDB. 
 
1.  Regional Benchmarking and Development Planning 
10.  Regional benchmarking will lead to the collection, analysis, and comparison of key 
provincial performance data (technical, financial, institutional, and customer service). It will 
serve as an effective management, monitoring, and planning tool to help address localized 
problems  and  improve  overall  performance.  Once  operating  baselines  are  determined, 
                                                 
12  Western RSC, Greater Colombo RSC, and the head office account for almost 50% of NWSDB’s staff resources, 
53% of NWSDB’s connections, and 65% of all drinking water produced. NWSDB. 2006. Annual Report. Colombo. 
13  Comprehensive benchmarking data is not available. Instead project survey data and random questionnaires 
conducted by the Mission were used.    
14  To achieve improved performance, NWSDB is revising its internal structure. As part of the proposed activities, the 
establishment of 11 RSCs (one per province, Greater Colombo, and headquarters) is soon to be confirmed.

4   
diagnoses, targets, time-bound action plans, and financial requirements will be determined in 
the form of a development or business plan for each of the 11 projected RSCs.  
 
2.  Capacity Development for Decentralized Service Delivery  
11.  In parallel and as an essential part of improved service delivery in every RSC, a human 
resource review will be conducted and a capacity development program provided to improve 
staff capacity. Activities will include (i) preparation of training needs assessments for each of the 
RSCs; (ii) development of training programs and manuals in the fields of management of 
operations, capital investment planning, accounting and financial management, auditing, and 
nonrevenue water; and (iii) delivery of the training programs across the country. In line with 
objective  5.2  of  the  corporate  plan,  the  TA  will  prepare  a  time-bound  program  for 
decentralization  of  responsibilities;  this  will  be  carefully  considered  in  formulating  training 
programs, particularly where human resource gaps are identified. 
 
3.  NWSDB Asset Management and Planning  
12.  Based on information collected from the RSCs, baseline data will be reviewed and 
analyzed at the national level. Subsequently, through a process of consultation and review of 
the existing corporate plan and its targets as well as regional development plans, the TA will 
develop a 5-year asset management plan for NWSDB as an organization. NWSDB’s corporate 
and business plan may be updated based on the outcomes of the consultation and financial 
constraints identified, if any. 
 
4.  Facilitating Internal Monitoring and Regulation  
13.  To catalyze the implementation of internal monitoring systems as well as technical and 
economic regulation, the TA will support NWSDB in developing and implementing an agenda, 
including  working  plans  and  schedules.  Activities  and  associated  manuals  to  be  prepared 
include implementing and monitoring systems, reporting mechanisms, protocols, and reviews. 
The activities are expected to lead to NWSDB’s first submission for a rate review, and the 
regulator’s  first  review  and  approval.15 As  part  of  the  program,  the  following  activities  are 
envisaged: (i) short-term placements in established regulatory bodies in the region, (ii) focus 
training,  and  (iii) on-the-job  advisory  services  for  the  preparation  of  reporting  systems  and 
reviews.16  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000 equivalent. The Cooperation Fund for the Water 
Sector17 will provide $50,000 equivalent on a grant basis; ADB will administer the grant. ADB 
will  provide  $700,000  equivalent  on  a  grant  basis  from  ADB’s  TA  funding  program.18 The 
Government  will  contribute  the  remaining  $250,000  in  kind  or  otherwise,  including  office 
accommodation and utilities, counterpart staff, background reports, and workshop facilities. 
Detailed cost estimates and the financing plan are provided in Appendix 2. 
                                                 
15  Additional related data required in support of NWSDB’s first submission to the regulator, such as financial 
projections and tariff setting computed using the existing model, will be utilized. The model was developed with 
ADB’s assistance (footnote 9)  
16  This activity is contingent on parliamentary approval of the NWSDB Act amendments. The amendments should 
include provisions establishing formal and legal linkages between PUCSL and NWSDB.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  MWSD and NWSDB will be executing and implementing agencies, respectively, of this 
TA. NWSDB will (i) appoint a TA unit coordinator, who will have a supportive, coordinating, and 
facilitating role;19 and (ii) provide office space, furniture, equipment, and technical and support 
counterpart  staff  to  the  TA  as  necessary.  Overall  guidance  for  TA  implementation  will  be 
provided by the TA steering committee, which will be headed by the Secretary of MWSD and 
include senior officials from other government agencies, including the Ministry of Finance and 
Planning,  NWSDB,  PUCSL,  and  representatives  from  development  partner  agencies.  The 
steering committee will first meet upon submission of the first consultant’s report and no later 
than  4 weeks  after  the  start  of  the  TA  to  confirm  NWSDB  board  formal  approval  of  a 
decentralized program of functions. The TA is proposed to be implemented over 9 months from 
September 2008 to June 2009. A team of international and national consultants will be selected 
and recruited through a firm using the quality- and cost-based selection method to provide a 
total  of  76.5  person-months  of  consulting  services:  14.5  person-months  of  international 
consulting,  and  62  person-months  of  national  consulting.  The  international  consultants  will 
include  experts  in  water  utility  institutions,  financial  management  and  tariffs,  commercial 
operations,  and  water  sector  regulations.  The  national  consultants  will  include  experts  in 
financial  analysis,  training,  environment  and  safety  compliance,  auditing,  human  resource 
management,  evaluation  and  monitoring,  customer  services,  project accounting,  and  water 
engineering. ADB will select and engage the consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Outline terms of reference for 
TA consultants are presented in Appendix 3.  
  
16.  ADB’s full technical proposal will be used in selecting consultants. Extensive workshops 
and consultations will be conducted under the TA, as these are essential to secure ownership 
and knowledge transfer. Office equipment financed by the TA will be procured in accordance 
with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time) and handed over to 
the Government on completion of the TA activities. The consultants will submit four major 
reports: (i) an inception report no later than 4 weeks following the commencement of services, 
(ii) an interim report within 5 months, (iii) a draft report at the end of the 8th month, and (iv) a 
final report within 4 weeks of receiving Government and ADB comments on the draft report. The 
consultants  will  submit  short  monthly  progress  notes  summarizing  TA  activities,  issues, 
constraints, and proposed solutions. Tripartite meetings will be held with ADB, Government 
representatives, and the consultants to review the inception, midterm, and draft final reports and 
verify accomplishments. The consultants will translate the TA key deliverables to facilitate their 
review by the Government and stakeholders. The TA will also recruit an individual international 
consultant for 4 person-months to improve project management practices within NWSDB. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $50,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Cooperation Fund for the Water Sector; and (ii) ADB providing 
the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis, to the Government of 
Sri Lanka for Institutional Strengthening for Decentralized Service Delivery in the Water Sector, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.  
                                                 
19  The TA coordinator is expected to be able to devote at least 2 full days per week to this TA.

A.  Overview 
1.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  require  14.5  person-months  of  international  and 
62 person-months of national consulting services over 9 months (Table A3.1). The work under 
the TA is divided into four parts: (i) benchmarking, (ii) development and asset management 
planning,  (iii)  strengthening  the  capacity  of  regional  service  centers  (RSCs)  to  undertake 
decentralized  functions,  and  (iv) development  of  the  expertise  and  skill  of  institutions 
responsible for implementing water sector regulations. The consultants will use a participatory 
approach throughout the assignment and no less than 75%–80% of their time will be spent 
working in regional offices. The TA and consultants’ assignments are structured in accordance 
with expected outputs.

B.  Part A: Benchmarking (2.5 months) 
2.   Benchmarking  (both  as  an  output  and  as  a  process)  will  be  developed  to  support 
collaborative learning by the RSCs and the corporate planning section of National Water Supply 
and  Drainage  Board  (NWSDB).  It  will  focus  on  specific  operating  practices,  comparing 
measures and results, and identifying improved processes for each region. Key components will 
include  (i)  data  gathering  in  the  form  of  detailed  surveys  of  measures  and  processes; 
(ii) identification of best performance, best practices, and any reasons for deviation; and (iii) site 
visits, where best practice is relevant. 
 
3.   Benchmarking will help improve sector efficiencies and adequately develop responses to 
demand. The team of consultants will conduct a benchmarking exercise in all 11 RSCs.1 The 
consultants will

(i)  conduct one or two opening workshops to (a) introduce benchmarking concepts 
and objectives to RSC managers, and (b) jointly develop and agree on most

4.   This study is expected to be comprehensive and include areas such as (i) general 
information,  (ii)  service  area  and  service  provision,  (iii)  infrastructure  description, 
(iv) consumption and production, (v) system performance and system reliability, (vi) staff and

5.  In  addition,  the  consultants  will  (i)  develop  and,  if  necessary,  restructure  the  data

communication requirements with regulatory agencies.   
 
C.  Part B: Institutional Strengthening and Planning (6 months) 
6.   Phase  I:  Regional  Development  Planning.  Using  baseline  regional  data  and 
diagnoses prepared for each RSC, the consultants will undertake the following: 
 
(i)  Establish realistic targets for overall improvement.

in  service  performance  over  time.  Indicators  may  focus  on  quality,  efficiency,  affordability,  or  comparative 
performance. Some may be expressed as indexes adjusted for different operating conditions. 
3  For this assignment, each team is expected to spend at least 2–3 days with each RSC. 
4  The diagnosis may be made in relation to the overall and RSC-based management structure, operating efficiency, 
policies, and cost recovery.

responsibility, population in service area, population served, number of towns served); (iii) infrastructure description 
(raw  water  source,  treatment  method,  production  capacity,  distribution  length,  storage  capacity,  number  of 
connections,  operating  water  meters,  service  connection  length);  (iv)  consumption  and  production  (RSC 
production,  bulk  water  bought,  metered  consumption,  unmetered  consumption,  meter  inaccuracy,  water 
billed/sold), (v) system performance (intermittent supply, supply duration, water main pressure, water main pipe 
breaks, residual chlorine tests required/performed/passed); (vi) staff (employment type, number of staff, training 
event participation, number of training days, human resource development expenditure); (vii) customers (number of 
new  customers,  number  of  customer  complaints,  means  of  complaining,  ways  to  understand  customers, 
connection charges, fixed water supply charges, consumption charges, lower slab cubic meter/month water bill); 
(viii) finance (water supply revenue, end-of-year accounts receivable, RSC operating expenses, water supply 
operating expenses); and (ix) capital investment (source of funds, gross fixed asset values, debt servicing costs).

(iii)  Review RSC structure and propose amendments to its human resource base, as 
required. 
(iv)  Where relevant, prepare simplified financial projections to support the proposals.7 
(v)  Based on these, prepare RSC-specific business development plans. and 
(vi)  Prepare reporting programs outlining frequencies of reliable data collection and

7.  In parallel, the consultants will review the recently completed asset register and its 
valuation,8 and prepare a program for the RSCs to formulate asset management plans. The 
RSCs will need to commit to allocating the necessary human resources. The consultants will

(i)  Prepare a (a) common framework, (b) property information system,9 (c) clear 
methodology for assessing the condition of physical assets,10 (d) methodology for 
suitability and sufficiency assessments,11 and (e) methodology for formulating an

(ii)  Conduct workshops for RSC staff to (a) introduce concepts, (b) present case

(d) provide a time frame for completion of data collection and classification by 
each RSC.

RSC technical and managerial staff on how to translate asset condition data and

frame for completion of the RSC asset management plans.

plans,  the  consultants  will  (i)  review  draft  business  objectives  and  financial  projections 
undertaken by NWSDB’s financial department; (ii) review NWSDB’s corporate plan (2007–2011)

and its goals; and (iii) review NWSDB’s business operations and processes,12 and business

9.  Based on these activities (para. 8) and phase I findings, the consultants will (i) prepare a 
consolidated NWSDB asset management plan and (ii) update, as required, the existing NWSDB 
corporate and 5-year business plan. The process will be iterative and revisions to RSC plans 
will  be  conducted  in  consultation  with  NWSDB’s  planning  departments.  The  process  will 
conclude with a workshop to present findings and ensure full acceptance of all stakeholders.  
 
D.  Part C: Capacity Development for Decentralized Service Delivery (5 months) 
10.  In line with NWSDB’s self-identified objectives of improving service delivery through the 
transfer of a greater number of functions to its regional offices and based on the diagnosis 
assessment conducted in part A of the assignment, the consultants will review the capacity of 
the RSCs and their human resources, and suggest means for improvement as follows: 
 
(i)  Conduct a training needs assessment for each RSC.  
(ii)  Prepare a time-bound program of decentralization of responsibilities. 
(iii)  Review work conducted by financial management, audit, human resource, and 
commercial and administration sections; and provide recommendations wherever 
necessary. 
(iv)  Develop training programs and simple manuals13 for use in the management of 
field  operations  (with  particular  emphasis  on  nonrevenue  water), 14  capital 
investment  planning,  accounting  and  financial  management,  administrative 
services, auditing, and management.  
(v)  Deliver training programs across the country. 
 
E.  Part D: NWSDB Internal Monitoring and Regulation (4–5 months) 
11.  To catalyze this process, the TA will support NWSDB in developing and implementing an 
agenda (inclusive of working plans and schedules) to operationalize internal monitoring systems 
and accountable regulation. Specific deliverables include the following: 
 
(i)  Prepare a 2-year activity program outlining specific actions for implementation (and 
identifying financial resources associated with it). 
(ii)  Prepare and implement monitoring systems, reporting mechanisms, protocols, and 
reviews; and support both agencies (utility and regulator) in the preparation and 
submission of the first official documentation set. 
(iii)  Based on the 5-year business plan and agreed tariff methodology, support NWSDB 
to submit its first rate review and the regulator’s review and approval.
